Comments_List: Sociological knowledge, knowledge of organizational theories.  Developed skills in connecting theories and communicating these connections effectively. Logical decompositions.

I had very little knowledge about organizational theory before taking this course, so I gained a lot of knowledge in the different subfields of organizational behavior, from classic through modern papers.

- interpret and evaluate OT theory
- an introduction to the different fields of OT
- potential research ideas for future projects
- general insights into academia
A systematic understanding of the fields within organizational theory.

Strengths - because the class was small, discussion was lively and engaging; everyone was able to contribute. The papers were interesting and the course was organized in an effective way.
Weaknesses - the logical decompositions were difficult without formal training in theory construction.

I really liked the structure of this course. It was completely discussion based which was very helpful in understanding the different papers and theories we were covering. The small size of the class was also a strength of the course because it really allowed everyone to have in depth conversations about the readings.
I was quite happy with the course.

Great summaries of the field from the Professor. A good balance of teaching and discussion. The literature review was particularly helpful. It would be nice if we could spend some more time on developing skills for such reviews. One way might be to have one assignment be writing the review and the next revising it.

This is a required course, but I would recommend it even if it weren't. I thought this was a great course in both content and structure, and I learned a ton about the organizational literature by taking it.
As long as there is interest in OT, the course seemed like a great introduction into the field while still being rigorous enough in its approach
Yes, I would recommend this to students interested in the development and recent trends of organizational theory.
